unnormalised: Okay, so petrol prices, right? Everyone’s talking about them, especially since they seem to change more often than the auto-rickshaw fare in Mumbai. It’s all about litres, kilometers, and that dreaded Rs. symbol. You fill your bike, check the mileage, and then silently pray that the next time you go to the petrol pump, the rate hasn't jumped up by ₹2 overnight.
normalised: Okay, so petrol prices, right? Everyone's talking about them, especially since they seem to change more often than the auto-rickshaw fare in Mumbai. It's all about litres, kilometers, and that dreaded rupee symbol. You fill your bike, check the mileage, and then silently pray that the next time you go to the petrol pump, the rate hasn't jumped up by rupee two overnight.

unnormalised: I remember when petrol used to be, like, Rs. 50 a litre. Now, you're staring at a price tag closer to ₹100 per L, depending on where you are. Delhi might be a bit cheaper than Chennai, and some states have those extra taxes that make your wallet weep a little extra. It’s enough to make you consider switching to an electric scooter, but then you remember the charging time, the initial cost of the scooter, and the nagging range anxiety of whether you can actually make it back home on a single charge. That battery capacity is usually measured in kWh. For instance, most affordable e-scooters have a capacity of around 2.5 kWh.
normalised: I remember when petrol used to be, like, rupee fifty a litre. Now, you're staring at a price tag closer to rupee one hundred per liter, depending on where you are. Delhi might be a bit cheaper than Chennai, and some states have those extra taxes that make your wallet weep a little extra. It's enough to make you consider switching to an electric scooter, but then you remember the charging time, the initial cost of the scooter, and the nagging range anxiety of whether you can actually make it back home on a single charge. That battery capacity is usually measured in kilowatt hours. For instance, most affordable e-scooters have a capacity of around two point five kilowatt hours.

unnormalised: Then there’s the whole fuel efficiency thing. My uncle, he swears his old Maruti gives him 25 kmpl (kilometers per litre) on the highway. I think he's exaggerating. My car barely manages 15 km/l in the city, stop-start traffic and all. And the sales guy when I bought it promised me 20! That was probably when he was driving downhill with the wind behind him. Plus, the fuel tank capacity - around 40-45 liters - that seems to empty out faster than a biryani plate at a family gathering.
normalised: Then there's the whole fuel efficiency thing. My uncle, he swears his old Maruti gives him twenty five kilometers per litre on the highway. I think he's exaggerating. My car barely manages fifteen kilometers per litre in the city, stop-start traffic and all. And the sales guy when I bought it promised me twenty! That was probably when he was driving downhill with the wind behind him. Plus, the fuel tank capacity - around forty to forty five liters - that seems to empty out faster than a biryani plate at a family gathering.

unnormalised: And let's not even get started on CNG. The price per kg keeps fluctuating. Is it cheaper? Mostly, yeah. But you have to factor in the cost of converting your car, the waiting time at the CNG station (which can sometimes feel like you’re queuing up for a visa), and the fact that you have to lug around that extra tank. A CNG cylinder usually holds around 12 kg to 14 kg of gas.
normalised: And let's not even get started on C-N-G. The price per kilogram keeps fluctuating. Is it cheaper? Mostly, yeah. But you have to factor in the cost of converting your car, the waiting time at the C-N-G station (which can sometimes feel like you're queuing up for a visa), and the fact that you have to lug around that extra tank. A C-N-G cylinder usually holds around twelve kilograms to fourteen kilograms of gas.

unnormalised: I was just reading an article which mentioned that a new type of fuel is being tested in India. It is supposed to improve fuel efficiency by nearly 10% translating to an increase of ~ 2-3 kmpl.
normalised: I was just reading an article which mentioned that a new type of fuel is being tested in India. It is supposed to improve fuel efficiency by nearly ten percent translating to an increase of approximately two to three kilometers per litre.

unnormalised: Seriously, it’s enough to make you want to ditch the car altogether and just take the local train. But then you remember the peak hour crush and the sheer force required to squeeze yourself onto the carriage. So, you're back to the petrol pump, swiping your card, and wondering if anyone’s ever figured out a real solution to this fuel price madness. Maybe someday we’ll all be driving those futuristic hydrogen-powered cars, filling up with some exotic, cheap fuel, and laughing about the days when we used to worry about the price of petrol in Rs. per litre. But until then, it's just another ride on the fuel price rollercoaster, buckle up and prepone all your errands for when fuel is cheaper.
